awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Building an Open-Source Civic Data Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by Pathways to Enable Open-Source Ecosystems (POSE) which seeks to harness the power of open-source development for the creation of new technology solutions to problems of national and societal importance. Transparency, how easy it is to get reliable or truthful information about something, is essential to building trust in the government and holding leaders accountable.  Just over 15 years ago, the Comprehensive Knowledge Archive Network (CKAN) open-source data management software was developed, and it now powers open data and transparency initiatives around the world.  This includes the Data.gov platform, the U.S. government’s open data catalog, which makes hundreds of thousands of datasets accessible to everyone. This project develops a plan to strengthen CKAN so that the software can continue to provide an effective platform for open data, open government, and open science initiatives. The project’s novelties are reflected in the inclusive strategy the research team uses to engage interested parties in the CKAN ecosystem, and participants in civic data communities of practice. The project’s impacts include advancing CKAN’s values of democracy, transparency, and inclusiveness, as well as sustaining a vital open-source civic data infrastructure.

Members of the research team plan to map the current status of the CKAN ecosystem to allow the team members to visualize relationships and processes within the CKAN ecosystem. This ecosystem map will be used as a guide for engaging a diverse group of ecosystem users and contributors in conversations and interactive workshops to uncover issues related to growth and sustainability of the ecosystem. Issues to be explored include maintenance, incentives for contributing to the project, strengthening feedback mechanisms between CKAN users and ecosystem stewards, and improving the climate for CKAN adoption. After initial data are collected from the interviews and workshops, interested parties will participate in the analysis of the preliminary data through activities designed to contribute to a plan for OSE sustainability. The resulting plan will include developing an ecosystem governance model, processes for integrating innovation with the core CKAN product, and ensuring product competitiveness and overall sustainability of the product.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This POSE Phase I award enabled the development of a plan to strengthen the CKAN open source software ecosystem. The plan has been designed to improve the quality and sustainability of a vital civic data management platform that serves as infrastructure for many transparency and open data initiatives around the world, including data.gov, the U.S. Federal Government?s open data portal. At a time in which inequality, disinformation, misinformation and distrust are rising, it?s vital that civic data and information not be locked-away in proprietary platforms.

CKAN is widely used around the world. Our analysis found 381 active instances managed in 59 countries by national, state and local governments, academic institutions, non-governmental organizations, and for-profit organizations. The project is held in trust by the Open Knowledge Foundation, which has appointed two firms to serve as co-stewards of the software. The continuous development model is reliant on a distributed global network of over 300 contributors. A ?core tech team? composed of experienced CKAN software developers is responsible for managing the code base and maintaining security.

Engagement with leaders and other members of the CKAN community has provided an understanding of how the ecosystem operates. Through our ecosystem discovery efforts, we found a dedicated community of people connected by personal and structural affinities, along with an affinity to a product that can help people build a more open, inclusive, and transparent society. Activities supported by this award included semi-structured interviews with over 40 people that play different roles in the ecosystem, including stewards, core tech team members, consultants that use CKAN in their work, and adopting agencies from around the world. We also spoke with people that recently evaluated CKAN and competing products as part of a software selection process. These interviews were used to better understand perspectives, experiences, motivations, values, priorities, goals, and contexts. Our team also analyzed data about CKAN installations and developed an historical timeline of CKAN releases. This research also informed the design of a series of sense-making workshops, where members of the CKAN ecosystem shared ideas for strengthening the ecosystem. 

Investments to strengthen the CKAN ecosystem will allow people from around the world to continue working in solidarity to build the open future that they want to see into the project?s third decade. High-priority investments identified in our Phase I work include: 1. Creating clearly-defined onboarding pathways that will welcome and encourage people underrepresented in technology communities to make a meaningful contribution to the ecosystem; 2. Developing new scaffolding for community participation that members of the ecosystem can use to design, organize, and manage new activities and events; 3. Increasing promotion of CKAN and expanding technical assistance to help people install the product or upgrade to the current version; 4; Refreshing the business model and fundraising strategy to account for a changing open data and open society landscape; and 5. Creation of a system to generate performance measures that members of the ecosystem can use to monitor its health into the future.
